sections.title: Clinical care for jaw tension, facial pain, and therapeutic injectables
sections.body: Facial therapeutics focus on comfort and function where appropriate, with careful assessment and conservative planning.
bullets: Full medical review before any intervention, including medicines and contraindications
Pathways across clenching relief, facial pain management, and TMJ symptom support
Measured dosing and clear safety guidance for any prescription injectable care

sections.title: Medical assessment, conservative first
items: History and examination covering bite, muscle activity, joint range, and relevant medical factors
Conservative options such as bite guards, self-care, and physiotherapy signposting explored before injections
Therapeutic injectables offered only when suitable, using prescription products with aseptic technique
Escalation protocols for red flags, including when to seek urgent dental or medical review

sections.title: Understand symptoms before choosing a pathway
sections.body: We explore jaw tightness, clenching, headaches, and TMJ clicks or locking. Examination may include muscle palpation, bite assessment, and range-of-motion checks. We discuss conservative measures first and explain when therapeutic injectables are appropriate.
bullets: Medical history, medication review, and contraindication screening
Jaw and muscle assessment with attention to wear facets and trigger points
Advice on self-care, guards, or physiotherapy signposting before medication
Clear explanation of benefits, limits, and follow-up for any injectable treatment
Safety guidance on when to seek urgent care if pain, swelling, or locking escalates

sections.title: Patients needing clinically led relief
items: Clenching or bruxism causing jaw fatigue, tooth wear, or morning discomfort
Facial pain or headache patterns linked to muscle tension or TMJ strain
TMJ clicks, stiffness, or intermittent locking that benefit from conservative management
Patients suitable for muscle-relaxing injectables once assessment supports this route
People who want clear limits on what injectables can and cannot achieve

sections.title: Assess, stabilise, treat, and review
items: Initial assessment of symptoms, triggers, and medical considerations
Conservative measures: bite guards, habit coaching, stretches, and lifestyle guidance
Therapeutic injectables: considered when indicated to relax overactive muscles
Follow-up to monitor relief, adjust dosing, or adapt guard fit
Escalation: referral, imaging, or urgent care if red flags appear
sections.strapline: Treatment proceeds only when safe and clinically justified. Timelines depend on response to conservative steps and any prescribed injectables.

sections.title: Regulated medicines, sterile technique, and documented dosing
sections.body: Prescription-only medicines are sourced through regulated pharmacies, stored appropriately, and administered with anatomical mapping. Notes cover batch numbers, sites, and doses so subsequent visits remain safe and traceable.
sections.mediaHint: Clinical injectables prepared with sterile single-use equipment

sections.title: Practical guidance and escalation points
items: Written aftercare covering hygiene, posture, and how to monitor muscle response
What to avoid after injections or when wearing guards, including strenuous exercise and pressure on treated sites
Risks discussed plainly: bruising, transient weakness, asymmetry, infection, or vascular events with clear action steps

faqs.question: Do I need a consultation before any treatment?
faqs.answer: Yes. We only proceed after a clinical assessment that reviews your medical history, medicines, and symptoms, then confirms whether conservative care or injectables are appropriate.

faqs.question: Are therapeutic injectables the same as cosmetic toxin treatments?
faqs.answer: No. Here they are used for symptom relief in carefully selected muscles, not for cosmetic aims. Doses, targets, and follow-up are chosen for function and comfort.

faqs.question: What if conservative steps are enough?
faqs.answer: If self-care, guards, or physiotherapy resolve symptoms, we continue monitoring without injectables. Medicine is only added when clinically beneficial.

faqs.question: When should I seek urgent care?
faqs.answer: Contact us or emergency services if you notice jaw locking, severe swelling, breathing changes, or visual symptoms after any facial treatment.

faqs.question: Who delivers the treatment?
faqs.answer: A prescriber trained in facial anatomy, complication management, and escalation pathways carries out your care and remains available for review.
